newsitem.title: USA: BOXING-EX-WORLD BOXING CHAMP JORDAN BEATEN INTO COMA.
newsitem.headline: BOXING-EX-WORLD BOXING CHAMP JORDAN BEATEN INTO COMA.

text.p: Homicide detectives on Thursday were investigating the beating of former world welterweight boxing champion Don Jordan, who was reported to be in a coma 11 days after the assault.

Officials at the Harbour-UCLA Medical Centre declined to discuss Jordan's condition, but the Los Angeles Times quoted friends and relatives as saying the 62-year-old ex-fighter was in critical condition on life-support in the intensive care unit.

Jordan, the one-time "Geronimo Kid" who won the world welterweight title in 1958 from Virgil Akins, was beaten in broad daylight on Sept. 30 in the Los Angeles suburb of Wilmington, a tough waterfront neighbourhood, police said.
A Los Angeles police spokesman said the case had been taken over by homicide investigators and that they had several leads, including witnesses.
Even though Jordan had not died as a result of the beating, it was considered a serious enough crime for the homicide squad to get involved, the spokesman said.
Detectives told the Times that robbery may have been the motive and that a weapon, possibly a pipe, was used.
Jordan defended his title successfully in a rematch with Akins but only held the world title for two years before his career went into a tail-spin.
His last fight in 1962 ended with Jordan hitting the canvas in the first round and staying down.
He was disqualified for "not trying" but an investigation failed to prove he took a dive. Jordan later denied in an interview with the Times he had thrown the fight.
